liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations says it has been told by the Israeli military that some 1.1 million Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours. However, UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences". "The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said. Mr Dujarric said the order by the Israeli military also applied to all UN staff and those sheltered in UN facilities, including schools, health centres and clinics.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli military warns over 1 million Gazans to relocate south, United Nations says

children.content: The United Nations says it has been told by the Israeli military that some
1.1 million
Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours.
However, UN spokesman
Stephane Dujarric
said that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences".
"The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said.
Mr Dujarric said the order by the Israeli military also applied to all UN staff and those sheltered in UN facilities, including schools, health centres and clinics.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Palestine Action Group has responded to news that NSW Police is considering using extraordinary powers at a rally at Sydney's Hyde Park planned for this Sunday. The group says the move is an attack on their right to demonstrate in solidarity with the people of Palestine, and it is important for them to express their views in the wake of the international community failing to intervene over the loss of human life in Gaza. Josh Lees from the Palestine Action Group says he believes the government wants to crack down on pro-Palestine protests because of "Israel's plan to unleash atrocities on Gaza". "Mr Netanyahu himself said that we're only getting started. The Israeli defence minister called the Palestinian people animals and openly talked about carrying out a basic genocide in Gaza and our governments in the West are giving them carte blanche rearming them, like the United States announced this morning," he said. "Our governments are complicit in the crimes that are about to be unleashed on the people of Gaza. That's why it is more important than ever the people come out to protest … This is a genocide we're talking about, that they will unleash on the people of Gaza, we have to keep protesting against that." Peter Slezak from Independent Jewish Voices says attempts to smear these rallies as anti-Semitic are wrong. "I'm proud to stand as many Jews on behalf of the people who stand up for human rights and for international law to condemn what the state of Israel is doing with the complicity and the help of our own governments and the big powers around the world," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pro-Palestinian group responds as NSW Police considers using special powers at next rally

props.alt: A close up of a man speaking outside, with another man behind him near a tree

children.content: (ABC News)
The Palestine Action Group has responded to news that NSW Police is considering using extraordinary powers at a rally at Sydney's Hyde Park planned for this Sunday.

The group says the move is an attack on their right to demonstrate in solidarity with the people of Palestine, and it is important for them to express their views in the wake of the international community failing to intervene over the loss of human life in Gaza.
Josh Lees from the Palestine Action Group says he believes the government wants to crack down on pro-Palestine protests because of "Israel's plan to unleash atrocities on Gaza".

"Mr Netanyahu himself said that we're only getting started. The Israeli defence minister called the Palestinian people animals and openly talked about carrying out a basic genocide in Gaza and our governments in the West are giving them carte blanche rearming them, like the United States announced this morning," he said.

"Our governments are complicit in the crimes that are about to be unleashed on the people of Gaza. That's why it is more important than ever the people come out to protest … This is a genocide we're talking about, that they will unleash on the people of Gaza, we have to keep protesting against that."
Peter Slezak from Independent Jewish Voices says attempts to smear these rallies as anti-Semitic are wrong.

"I'm proud to stand as many Jews on behalf of the people who stand up for human rights and for international law to condemn what the state of Israel is doing with the complicity and the help of our own governments and the big powers around the world," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Aside from the already announced Qantas flights leaving Israel for London in the coming days, the Australian government has now announced at least two charter flights which will take Australians from Tel Aviv to Dubai. Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong and Transport Minister Catherine King say Qantas has also agreed to fly Australians arriving in London (from Tel Aviv) to Sydney via Singapore free of charge. "The Australian government will continue to work on options for onward travel from Dubai and to support those who cannot reach Tel Aviv," the ministers say in a press release. The government says Australians in Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories who want to leave and don't already have plans to depart should register via DFAT's Crisis Porta l or by calling the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian government announces more repatriation flights from Israel

"The Australian government will continue to work on options for onward travel from Dubai and to support those who cannot reach Tel Aviv," the ministers say in a press release.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Matt Garrick Former Northern Territory chief minister Clare Martin says she believes a Voice to Parliament would have prevented the NT Intervention in 2007, which saw the Australian Federal Police and defence force members sent into remote communities across the territory. More than 15 years since the Intervention, many Aboriginal leaders say it left NT communities disempowered and disenfranchised, and contributed to the level of social issues faced today. Ms Martin was the Labor NT government's leader when then-prime minister John Howard's Coalition triggered the Intervention, to try to combat what it believed at the time was a surge in sexual assaults against children. "If there's ever anywhere that needs a strong national Voice to stop federal governments doing really stupid things in the territory, then it's this Voice," Ms Martin said. "I'm a product of the Intervention, which John Howard did because he wanted to win votes elsewhere. "That was an extraordinary waste of money and a damage for Aboriginal people. "If we had a Voice, we would never have had an Intervention." Mr Howard last week told an Australians for Constitutional Monarchy conference that he defended his government's decision to start the Intervention, saying it was a "recognition that … the Northern Territory Government, had completely failed in its responsibilities".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former NT chief minister says a Voice would have prevented NT Intervention

props.alt: Clare Martin looking toward the camera in front of an out of focus YES campaign sign

children.content: (ABC News: Tristan Hooft)
By Matt Garrick
Former Northern Territory chief minister
Clare Martin

says she believes a Voice to Parliament would have prevented the NT Intervention in 2007, which saw the Australian Federal Police and defence force members sent into remote communities across the territory.
More than 15 years since the Intervention, many Aboriginal leaders say it left NT communities disempowered and disenfranchised, and
contributed to the level of social issues faced today

Ms Martin was the Labor NT government's leader when then-prime minister John Howard's Coalition triggered the Intervention, to try to combat what it believed at the time was a surge in sexual assaults against children.
"If there's ever anywhere that needs a strong national Voice to stop federal governments doing really stupid things in the territory, then it's this Voice," Ms Martin said.
"I'm a product of the Intervention, which John Howard did because he wanted to win votes elsewhere.
"That was an extraordinary waste of money and a damage for Aboriginal people.
"If we had a Voice, we would never have had an Intervention."
Mr Howard last week told an Australians for Constitutional Monarchy conference
that he defended his government's decision to start the Intervention, saying it was a "recognition that … the Northern Territory Government, had completely failed in its responsibilities".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Smith South Australia's Opposition Leader David Speirs and Liberal Senator Kerrynne Liddle, who are both advocating for a No vote, spoke outside a pre-polling booth in the coastal suburb of Brighton this morning. Mr Speirs urged people to "remain respectful and decent" during the voting process. "This is an important part of democracy and we ought to respect it and respect each other's views," he said. Mr Speirs said South Australians he had spoken to were "confused" about the Voice. "They're really concerned about the serious lack of detail that has been put on the table by the prime minister. And the prime minister is going to have a lot of questions to answer on Sunday morning if, as predicted, the referendum is defeated across Australia," he said. Ms Liddle, an Arrernte woman, said people should focus on the facts when they make their decision, not emotion. "It is about a whole new chapter in our constitution, in our nation's rulebook, and anything you do to our rulebook has consequences," she said. "That's why Australians have been very careful historically in making any change to our rulebook — and they should be. "And they should be really careful on this one too, because they shouldn't be voting on emotion. "They shouldn't be voting because they feel like they're being intimidated, harassed, or ashamed or guilted. None of those things should come into play here."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: State Opposition Leader David Speirs says South Australians 'confused' about Voice

children.content: South Australian opposition leader David Speirs and Liberal Senator Kerrynne Liddle
(ABC News)
Reporting by Matt Smith
South Australia's Opposition Leader
David Speirs
and Liberal Senator
Kerrynne Liddle
, who are both advocating for a No vote, spoke outside a pre-polling booth in the coastal suburb of Brighton this morning.
Mr Speirs urged people to "remain respectful and decent" during the voting process.
"This is an important part of democracy and we ought to respect it and respect each other's views," he said.
Mr Speirs said South Australians he had spoken to were "confused" about the Voice.

"They're really concerned about the serious lack of detail that has been put on the table by the prime minister. And the prime minister is going to have a lot of questions to answer on Sunday morning if, as predicted, the referendum is defeated across Australia," he said.
Ms Liddle, an Arrernte woman, said people should focus on the facts when they make their decision, not emotion.
"It is about a whole new chapter in our constitution, in our nation's rulebook, and anything you do to our rulebook has consequences," she said.
"That's why Australians have been very careful historically in making any change to our rulebook — and they should be.
"And they should be really careful on this one too, because they shouldn't be voting on emotion.
"They shouldn't be voting because they feel like they're being intimidated, harassed, or ashamed or guilted. None of those things should come into play here."

title.children: Inflation data reignites interest rate fears on Wall Street and ASX, while Israel-Gaza war sparks recession fears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You might recall the ABC did this story earlier this month about Argentina, where the inflation rate at the time was running at more than 100 per cent. Well, things are getting worse. The latest inflation rate data just came out for the South American country. Prices have gone up 12.7% in September and the annual figure is now 138%. In response, their central bank has hiked rates again from 118% to 133%. Many economists there think it will end the year at more than 180%. This all just comes 10 days before voters there go to the polls. The worsening surging prices have sapped wages and savings and pushed two out of every five people in Argentina below the poverty line. Inflation has been getting worse there since the government's near-18% devaluation of the peso in mid-August. A rapid freefall of Argentina's peso has since followed. Voters will be choosing who to succeed outgoing leftist President Alberto Fernandez, with radical libertarian Javier Milei seen as the front-runner due to his shock first-place showing in the August primary. Milei is seeking to shut the central bank and dollarize the economy to tame inflation. If you'd like more background on this situation, ABC's Foreign Correspondent had this great story this month.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Worried about a rate hike? Be lucky you're not in Argentina

Well, things are getting worse.
The latest inflation rate data just came out for the South American country. Prices have gone up 12.7% in September and the annual figure is now 138%.
In response, their central bank has hiked rates again from 118% to 133%.
Many economists there think it will end the year at more than 180%.
This all just comes 10 days before voters there go to the polls.
The worsening surging prices have sapped wages and savings and pushed two out of every five people in Argentina below the poverty line.
Inflation has been getting worse there since the government's near-18% devaluation of the peso in mid-August.
A
rapid freefall of Argentina's peso
has since followed.

Voters will be choosing who to succeed outgoing leftist President Alberto Fernandez, with radical libertarian Javier Milei seen as the front-runner due to his shock first-place showing in the August primary.
Milei is seeking to shut the central bank and dollarize the economy to tame inflation.
If you'd like more background on this situation, ABC's Foreign Correspondent had this great story this month.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The world's largest gold miner is set to take over Newcrest Mining after the Australian company's investors resoundingly voted in favour of this happening. Proxy votes came in at 91.66% in favour this morning, a slide shown to investors at a meeting in Melbourne showed. Newcrest Corporation's $26.2 billion bid for the company will be the largest corporate buyout in Australia this year. In May, Newcrest backed the takeover offer from Newmont. Both the companies expect the deal to close in early November. A final result will become known later on Friday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investors approve the biggest corporate buyout in Australia this year

children.content: The world's largest gold miner is set to take over Newcrest Mining after the Australian company's investors resoundingly voted in favour of this happening.
Proxy votes came in at 91.66% in favour this morning, a slide shown to investors at a meeting in Melbourne showed.
Newcrest Corporation's $26.2 billion bid for the company will be the largest corporate buyout in Australia this year.
In May,
Newcrest
backed the takeover offer from Newmont.
Both the companies expect the
deal to close in early November.
A final result will become known later on Friday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! The latest inflation data out of the US is spooking markets this morning. As you will see, Wall Street ended in the red and the futures for Australian markets show we will likely follow. The CPI data shows that price hikes aren't over in the world's biggest economy, with headline rising above consensus estimates by 0.3% a month and core inflation about the same. That, of course, is creating concern that the US federal reserve will raise rates again to tackle price spikes. This note from CBA this morning: Notwithstanding, we doubt the downtrend in inflation has been thrown off course.  The outlook for the US consumer is poor given the resumption of student loan repayments, lower government benefit payments, and the erosion of pandemic savings.  At the same time, interest rates on consumer loans have risen sharply to very high levels.  Indeed, some FOMC officials have recently said the rise in yields may substitute for further FOMC tightening.  Our baseline remains for the FOMC to keep the Funds rate steady into early 2024.  We consider the FOMC’s significant policy tightening will lead the global economy into recession. Recession fears are also being sparked by the devastating crisis in the Middle East. Here is a piece by our business reporter Nassim Khadem to get you started this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US inflation and Israel-Gaza war sparks global recession concerns

featuredLink.title: As Israel's war against Hamas escalates, US sends a warning to Iran, raising fears of a recession

children.content: Good morning!
The latest inflation data out of the US is spooking markets this morning. As you will see, Wall Street ended in the red and the futures for Australian markets show we will likely follow.
The CPI data shows that price hikes aren't over in the world's biggest economy, with headline rising above consensus estimates by 0.3% a month and core inflation about the same.
That, of course, is creating concern that the US federal reserve will raise rates again to tackle price spikes.
This note from CBA this morning:

Notwithstanding, we doubt the downtrend in inflation has been thrown off course.  The outlook for the US consumer is poor given the resumption of student loan repayments, lower government benefit payments, and the erosion of pandemic savings.  At the same time, interest rates on consumer loans have risen sharply to very high levels.  Indeed, some FOMC officials have recently said the rise in yields may substitute for further FOMC tightening.  Our baseline remains for the FOMC to keep the Funds rate steady into early 2024.  We consider the FOMC’s significant policy tightening will lead the global economy into recession.
Recession fears are also being sparked by the devastating crisis in the Middle East. Here is a piece by our business reporter Nassim Khadem to get you started this morning.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The AFL has confirmed St Kilda has not matched Essendon's bid, the Saints will receive pick 21 as compensation and Jade Gresham will become a Bomber. Now things can really start to get moving.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jade Gresham is officially a Bomber

children.content: (Getty Images)
The AFL has confirmed St Kilda has not matched Essendon's bid, the Saints will receive pick 21 as compensation and Jade Gresham will become a Bomber.
Now things can really start to get moving.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Continuing our series looking at the top draft prospects of 2023, we'll turn our attentions to a thrilling small forward set to become a fan favourite. There is no player in this draft as skilful as Nick Watson. He kicks goals most players couldn't dream of pulling off. He's a small forward who works hand all over the ground, and has had proven impact as a pinch-hitting midfielder. Sounds pretty good, right? What's the downside? The knock on Watson is he is 170cm tall. That makes him shorter than Caleb Daniel. But as Daniel, Brent Harvey and so many others have proven over the journey, height matters little when your football talent is immense enough. And in Watson's case, it certainly is. Concerns over his height won't be enough to deter clubs from making him a top-10 pick, but it might be enough to spook clubs right up the very top end. What is certain is that whoever picks him up is going to be treated to plenty of highlights, and one set of fans is going to have a new cult hero to love.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Nick Watson

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Lions have released a statement regarding Gunston's request to return to Hawthorn. "The Brisbane Lions confirm Jack Gunston has informed the club of his desire to return to Hawthorn. "While understanding Jack's situation, as a contracted player the club is assessing its position and will work through its options. "The club won't be providing further comment at this time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brisbane confirm Jack Gunston trade request

"While understanding Jack's situation, as a contracted player the club is assessing its position and will work through its options.
"The club won't be providing further comment at this time."
